story:
About This Campaign

My name is Nina Bruce. I have taken over this campaign on behalf of my husband Chris and our families and immediate friends who have urged me to do so. They, like me, can no longer afford the kidney dialysis treatment he so desperately needs  and we have exhausted our own funds.

Chris's Story

Chris before his kidney failure:

Chris retired three in 2011 having worked all his life from the age of twenty and was looking forward to a quiet life in retirement. Unfortunately he was diagnosed as having Type 2 Diabetes and End Stage Kidney Failure after he had twice collapsed and gone into a coma. After two months in hospital he is back home but requires regular kidney dialysis which is very expensive and Chris has a very small pension, but no medical insurance and his savings have been wiped out by his medical bills. Chris is a fighter and is doing everything he can to help himself but he needs the dialysis treatment to keep him alive.  

In better days Chris was an active contributor to charity including putting 6 students through university. He now needs your help.

Chris writes in the hope of making a little money with his recipe and humor books and autobiography but without the income to support the dialysis he desperately needs he will slowly lose his fight against this incurable disease.

Chris in a coma in the ICU:

Objective

Our objective is to raise enough money to pay for Chris's ongoing dialysis and other medical expenses to allow him to live a little longer and to enjoy some rest and peace after working for 51 years.

Perks

The books Chris has written are offered in return for a donation. You can choose a perk in return for any donation of US$ 3 or more. These will be emailed to you together with a thank you note as soon as the campaign ends or Indiegogo gives me access to your email addresses. If after reading your perk of choice you would like to order another eBook please email me at chrisbruce41@gmail.com and I will email your further choice free of charge. Please click on GALLERY at the top left hand side of the page if you would like to see the front covers of the books and read a little more detail about them.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Even if you can’t contribute cash your help, in any form, will be appreciated. Please help me spread the word about my campaign and the book perks in any way you can – by word of mouth,  Twitter, Facebook, Instagram and any other social media. Please tell your family and friends of my plight. 

HAPPY CHRISTMAS

It’s Christmas Day today and I wish everyone who reads this appeal a very Happy Christmas and an equally happy and prosperous New Year.

Nina Bruce
story_txt:
About This Campaign




My name is Nina Bruce. I have taken over this campaign on behalf of my husband Chris and our families and immediate friends who have urged me to do so. They, like me, can no longer afford the kidney dialysis treatment he so desperately needs  and we have exhausted our own funds.
Chris's Story
Chris before his kidney failure:


Chris retired three in 2011 having worked all his life from the age of twenty and was looking forward to a quiet life in retirement. Unfortunately he was diagnosed as having Type 2 Diabetes and End Stage Kidney Failure after he had twice collapsed and gone into a coma. After two months in hospital he is back home but requires regular kidney dialysis which is very expensive and Chris has a very small pension, but no medical insurance and his savings have been wiped out by his medical bills. Chris is a fighter and is doing everything he can to help himself but he needs the dialysis treatment to keep him alive.  
In better days Chris was an active contributor to charity including putting 6 students through university. He now needs your help.
Chris writes in the hope of making a little
money with his recipe and humor books and autobiography but without the income
to support the dialysis he desperately needs he will slowly lose his fight
against this incurable disease.
Chris in a coma in the ICU:


Objective
Our objective is to raise enough money to pay for Chris's ongoing dialysis and other medical expenses to allow him to live a little longer and to enjoy some rest and peace after working for 51 years.
Perks
The books Chris has written are offered in return for a donation. You can choose a perk in return for any donation of US$ 3 or more. These will be emailed to you together with a thank you note as soon as the campaign ends or Indiegogo gives me access to your email addresses. If after reading your perk of choice you would like to order another eBook please email me at chrisbruce41@gmail.com and I will email your further choice free of charge. Please click on GALLERY at the top left hand side of the page if you would like to see the front covers of the books and read a little more detail about them.
OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP
Even
if you can’t contribute cash your help, in any form, will be appreciated.
Please help me spread the word about my campaign and the book perks in any way
you can – by word of mouth,  Twitter,
Facebook, Instagram and any other social media. Please tell your family and friends of my
plight. HAPPY CHRISTMASIt’s Christmas Day today and I wish everyone who reads this appeal a very Happy Christmas and an equally happy and prosperous New Year.Nina Bruce

story:
I need your help or I don't think I will make it. 

My name is Ellen Ulrich.  I am the mother of 2 and love my children very much.  I cherish every moment I have on this earth and would like to live a fulfilled and happy life. I  have fallen victim to the beasts of addiction and alcoholism. I am currently in a 28 day rehab program and need the money to pay for the rest of my stay.  It has caused me more grief and despair than I could have ever imagined and I need your help to pay for the remainder of my treatment. This has caused me lost memory and some brain damage as well as to break my sternum and countless emotional distress.  I will lose my life without your help.  I pray that indiegogo will allow me the ability to continue my current treatment and move on to a 90 day program to further reinforce my health and sobriety.  Thank you for all of your donations,  every penny means the world to me.

story:
Addendum dated 4/10/14 by Barb Pitcher, Administrator.


We reached our initial goal of $2300.00 within three days of launching our campaign. We are very grateful! These funds will be used for the payment plan set with the five medical establishments associated with Amy's treatments, only through October 2014. This campaign is open through April 30, in hopes that we can raise additional funds to pay the total costs of $6,350.00 not covered by insurance. Any additional contributions to this campaign will be applied directly to those medical establishments. Thank you!


Read on:


Dear Friends and Family,

At the beginning of February, Amy was diagnosed with Stage 2, breast cancer, Invasive Ductal Carcinoma. Two lymph nodes also tested positive. A very stressful February included a battery of other tests--Pet Scan, additional biopsies looking for metastasis, and the possibility of Inflammatory Breast Cancer which is more  aggressive and involves a poor prognosis. All came back negative! WHEW!


She has started chemo treatments, having had three so far, and will receive treatments through the end of July, and surgery, possible mastectomy, in the beginning of September. She is doing well at the time of this posting and has had mostly minor side effects. She has mainly had nausea and bone pain from the white blood cell booster shots (seven between every chemo treatment). She tires more easily and her hair has fallen out. She has been given a prescription for a “cranial prosthesis” (wig) but it doesn’t seem her style (see accompanying pictures). Hats and scarves will become the latest fashion statement!


True to Amy's nature, she dove into research about other alternative methods of treatment, and has found some fascinating research, especially on the use of curcumin, the active ingredient of turmeric. She is doing all she can to help this healing path.


Besides the emotional and physical stress, we are also experiencing the severe financial stress that this diagnosis brings. She is continuing to work, but only part time. Being self employed means there is no such thing as sick days, and NO sick pay. She anticipates not being back to full time work until November, depending largely on when and how extensive the surgery may be. Her income has been severely reduced, at a time when we can least afford it.


Amy has catastrophic insurance with Blue Care Network with a $6,350 total we have to pay ourselves. That amount seems small compared to the tens of thousands of dollars this journey will cost, but its a dollar figure that has sent us into a financial tail spin.  We are being proactive and have made arrangements for $50.00/month payments to the five entities involved: Johnson Cancer Center, Mercy Hospital, Muskegon Surgical Associates, anesthesiology, and radiology.  


We are asking for your help! These five new monthly payments ($250 per month), compounded by the costs of travel to medical appointments, and Amy’s loss of income are an additional financial burden on our budget, and we are struggling to make ends meet. We are requesting your help to make those medical payments each month. Your gift will ease the stress on Amy during this difficult time of treatments.


With Amy’s expected loss of eight months of work, we have established an initial need of $2,300 to cover our most pressing expenses. We are required to begin our monthly payment plans right away, so this Indiegogo fundraiser campaign will only be open for a short period of time. If you are so moved to contribute, we would need your donation by April 30, 2014.


Friends are also organizing a local fundraiser event to support Amy’s Healing Journey which will be on May 4, 2014.  Please contact us if you would like to donate food, time, silent auction items, or participate in any way.


Our hearts are open to this healing journey.  The doctors are very confident that this cancer can be eradicated, and Amy is convinced that she will be healthier than ever when all is done. Your financial help along this healing journey is held with deepest love and gratitude!  Thank you!  Amy and Barb

story:
HE NEEDS OUR SUPPORT!


On the evening of Aug. 21st, after leaving the movies together in downtown Cabo San Lucas and returning to my car to go enjoy dinner together, my boyfriend Eduardo Benitez was brutally attacked on the main boulevard in front of Puerto Paraiso mall.  Following an unfortunate altercation resulting from confronting an inconsiderate individual who was totally blocking us with his parked car, we were quickly surrounded by a group of his fellow employees from a bar across the street, and they were moving in.  In order to protect me and distract them, he ran as fast as possible in the opposite direction, and was immediately pursued at full speed down the sidewalk, through traffic, and across the boulevard by these multiple subjects, where they caught up to him and beat him unconscious with a barbaric weapon, leaving him for dead on the sidewalk.  


I'm so grateful for the miracle that he escaped with his life. 


This horrendously cold-blooded attack resulted in multiple fractures to his face:  his skull, cheeks, upper jaw, nose and the orbital bones under his eyes require extensive reconstruction with titanium mesh, plates, screws, etc.  Later, he will require extensive dental work to fix the multiple fractures he received to his teeth and molars.  Who knows what other consequences he may face health-wise.  

 

Now, almost 2 weeks later, following hosts of costly tests, scans, countless appointments and consultations with doctors both locally and internationally, Eduardo has travelled to Mexico City in search of the best care, and currently awaits arduous and extensive facial reconstruction surgery there, to totally rebuild the crushed bones of his face.  Following that, it will be months of recuperation.  


Eduardo has already used what savings he had towards covering medical costs until now, but is far from being personally capable of covering the cost of urgently needed operations and recovery, as he had no medical insurance.


He is a very generous and caring person, who helps and inspires people daily.  Professionally, he is a practicing Lawyer, as well as a Certified Personal Trainer, combining two passions:  the Law, and Health & Fitness.  Less than one week before the incident, he had very successfully completed his most recent Triathalon, and was training hard in hope to compete in next year's IRONMAN competition here in Cabo.  He also was working towards buying a home.   


Now he needs extensive surgery, is unable to work, and his extremely active lifestyle as he knew it was violently altered with this to-date unpunished attack.


Eduardo would never ask, but he truly needs the help of friends, family and community to come together to help him through this difficult time and back onto the road of recovery.  Funds raised will go directly to him to help cover surgery, medical and recovery costs.  Let's help him  --  and in turn return some of the inspiration that he always gives to others  --  so he can get well as soon as possible and get back to being active and healthy again, and come home to keep working for well-being and justice! 


If you are able to contribute financially, we will be eternally grateful.  If not, we thank you kindly for reading and considering his situation, and only ask for your help to share this campaign and create more awareness.  

 

    THANK YOU SO VERY, VERY MUCH, 

    from the bottom of my heart...  and his!  

    Deena

    ÉL NECESITA NUESTRO APOYO!

    En la noche del 21 de agosto, después de salir del cine juntos en el centro de Cabo San Lucas y regresar a mi coche para ir a disfrutar de una cena juntos, mi novio Eduardo Benítez fue brutalmente atacado en el bulevar principal en frente del centro comercial Puerto Paraíso. Después de un desafortunado altercado producto de haber reclamado a una persona imprudente quien nos estaba bloqueando totalmente con su coche estacionado, fuimos rápidamente rodeados por un grupo de sus compañeros de trabajo del bar en frente del mall, y estaban acercándose, cerrando el circulo.  Con el fin de protegerme y distraerlos, Eduardo salió corriendo tan rápido como sea posible en la dirección opuesta, y fue inmediatamente seguido a toda velocidad por unos de los tipos por la banqueta y a través del tráfico, y por fin a través del boulevard, donde aun mas hombres llegaron, entre 5 – 7 hombres, golpeándolo brutalmente con un bárbaro arma, hasta dejarlo inconsciente, dejándolo por muerto en la banqueta.

    Estoy muy agradecida por el milagro que Eduardo escapó con su vida.

    Este horrible ataque a sangre fría dio lugar a múltiples fracturas en su cara: el cráneo, mejillas, mandíbula superior, la nariz y los huesos debajo de sus ojos requieren una amplia reconstrucción con malla de titanio, placas, tornillos, etc. Más tarde, se le requerirá un gran trabajo dental para solucionar las múltiples fracturas que recibió en sus dientes y muelas. Quién sabe qué otras consecuencias de salud puede tener que enfrontar.

    Ahora, casi 2 semanas más tarde, después de multiples pruebas costosas, escaneos, innumerables citas y consultas con médicos tanto a nivel local como internacional, Eduardo ha viajado a la Ciudad de México, en búsqueda de la mejor atención, y que en la actualidad espera una ardua y extensa cirugía de reconstrucción facial, para totalmente reconstruir las fracturas de huesos de su cara. Después de eso, meses de recuperación.

    Eduardo ya ha utilizado lo que tenia ahorrado con el fin de cubrir los gastos médicos hasta ahora, pero está lejos de ser personalmente capaz de cubrir el costo alto de las operaciones que necesita con urgencia, y la recuperación, como no tenía seguro médico.

    Él es una persona sumamente generoso y siempre cuidando y ayudando a los demás, quien inspira a la gente y ayuda diariamente. Profesionalmente, es un abogado, así como un entrenador personal certificado, combinando dos pasiones: el derecho, y la salud & condición física. Menos de una semana antes de los hechos, había completado con éxito su más reciente Triatlón, y había estado entrenando duro con la esperanza de competir en la próxima competencia IRONMAN aquí en Cabo. También estaba trabajando para comprar una casa.

    Ahora, él necesita cirugía extensa, no puede trabajar, y su estilo de vida tan activo como él lo disfrutaba fue violentamente cambiado con este ataque, lo cual hasta la fecha se ha quedado totalmente impune.

    Eduardo nunca pediría, pero sinceramente, él necesita la ayuda de amigos, familia y la comunidad, para que se unan a ayudarle a atravesar este difícil momento y volver al camino de la recuperación. Los fondos recaudados se destinarán directamente a él para ayudar a cubrir la cirugía, médicos y los costos de recuperación.  Ayudémoslo -  y a la vez devolverle la inspiración que siempre les da a los demás -  para que pueda sanarse lo antes posible y volver a ser activo y saludable, y llegar a casa a seguir trabajando por el bienestar y la justicia!

    Si usted es capaz de aportar una contribución financiera, estaremos eternamente agradecidos. Si no es así, muchas gracias por tomar el tiempo de leer su historia y considerar su situación, y sólo pedimos su ayuda para compartir esta campaña y crear más conciencia.

    MUCHAS, MUCHAS, MUCHAS GRACIAS,

    desde el fondo de mi corazón... y el suyo!

    Deena

story:
"It will hurt. It will take time. It will require dedication. It will require willpower...It requires sacrifice...But I promise you, when you reach your goal, it will be worth it."  


What's all the hullabaloo? 

Hi, I'm Kristen! I'm a young twenty-something residing in Rochester, NY where I work as Director of Strategic Initiatives at an awesome literary center called Writers & Books. When I'm not working, I enjoy reading, cooking, writing, and fitness. 

Recently, perhaps due to a quarter life crisis or a deeply buried masochism, I decided to embark on a new fitness journey - the 30 Day Bikram Yoga Challenge. What is Bikram Yoga you ask? Bikram is a very specific kind of hot yoga practiced in a room heated to 105 degrees with 40% humidity. Each 90-minute session includes a series of 26 specific postures and 2 breathing exercises, which according to Rochester's Bikram Studio's website, are "designed for our cultural problems of stress, overeating, bad posture, and aggressive lifestyles."

So beginning Saturday, March 1st and going all the way through Sunday, March 30th, I am going to attend a Bikram class every single day. That means I will complete 45 hours, 1560 poses, and who knows how many loads of laundry in 30 days. Through literal sweat and probable tears, for better or for worse, I am going to stretch my body to it's limits and prove to myself that I can complete a yoga-thon. 

But I'm not only doing this for myself. 

In 2012, when I moved to Rochester and began working at Writers & Books, I quickly became fond and attached to one of my lovely co-workers, Sally Bittner Bonn. Over my first couple months at Writers & Books, I began to get to know Sally and later her husband, David, and her son, Oscar. The Merulla-Bonn family are three of the coolest people I know. They are poets, musicians, pirates. They are loving, warm, strong. And Oscar is by far the most erudite kindergartner I've ever met - full of curiosity, imagination, and giggles. 

Oscar was born with type-II Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA), a genetic neuromuscular disease characterized by muscle atrophy and weakness. You can learn more about it on the Oscar-Go website or on the FSMA website. Before meeting him and his family, I had never heard of SMA. Before meeting Sally, David, and Oscar I had never heard of SMA - I want to do this challenge for them and raise awareness and money to donate to SMA research. Help me raise funds, complete this challenge, and give back to a beautiful, inspiring community. 

Other Ways You Can Help! 

Every contribution, even a dollar, helps family's like Oscars. But as a recent college grad and entry-level worker, I understand that financial donations are not always possible. Here are other ways you can help support 30 Days for SMA:

  • Get the word out - both about this campaign and SMA! Post the link on twitter, facebook, tumblr, through email and any other social media site you frequent (the Indiegogo share tools are great for this!). And don't forget good old fashioned word of mouth! Talk it up to your family, friends, coworkers, strangers on the street! 

And finally...

For those interested, I will be posting my progress throughout the challenge on this blog (I intend to do it everyday, but let's not get too ahead of ourselves, hmm?). And here are some other helpful and interesting links: 

Oscar-Go 

FSMA Website

SMA Research 

Bikram Yoga

Bikram Rochester


With all my thanks and love, 

KZK

I'm a young twenty-something residing in Rochester, NY where I work as Director of Strategic Initiatives at an awesome literary center called Writers & Books. When I'm not working, I enjoy reading, cooking, writing, and fitness. Recently, perhaps due to a quarter life crisis or a deeply buried masochism, I decided to embark on a new fitness journey - the 30 Day Bikram Yoga Challenge. What is Bikram Yoga you ask? Bikram is a very specific kind of hot yoga practiced in a room heated to 105 degrees with 40% humidity. Each 90-minute session includes a series of 26 specific postures and 2 breathing exercises, which according to Rochester's Bikram Studio's website, are "designed for our cultural problems of stress, overeating, bad posture, and aggressive lifestyles."So beginning Saturday, March 1st and going all the way through Sunday, March 30th, I am going to attend a Bikram class every single day. That means I will complete 45 hours, 1560 poses, and who knows how many loads of laundry in 30 days. Through literal sweat and probable tears, for better or for worse, I am going to stretch my body to it's limits and prove to myself that I can complete a yoga-thon. But I'm not only doing this for myself. In 2012, when I moved to Rochester and began working at Writers & Books, I quickly became fond and attached to one of my lovely co-workers, Sally Bittner Bonn. Over my first couple months at Writers & Books, I began to get to know Sally and later her husband, David, and her son, Oscar. The Merulla-Bonn family are three of the coolest people I know. They are poets, musicians, pirates. They are loving, warm, strong. And Oscar is by far the most erudite kindergartner I've ever met - full of curiosity, imagination, and giggles. Oscar was born with type-II Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA), a genetic neuromuscular disease characterized by muscle atrophy and weakness. You can learn more about it on the Oscar-Go website or on the FSMA website. Before meeting him and his family, I had never heard of SMA. Before meeting Sally, David, and Oscar I had never heard of SMA - I want to do this challenge for them and raise awareness and money to donate to SMA research. Help me raise funds, complete this challenge, and give back to a beautiful, inspiring community. Other Ways You Can Help! Every contribution, even a dollar, helps family's like Oscars. But as a recent college grad and entry-level worker, I understand that financial donations are not always possible. Here are other ways you can help support 30 Days for SMA:Get the word out - both about this campaign and SMA! Post the link on twitter, facebook, tumblr, through email and any other social media site you frequent (the Indiegogo share tools are great for this!). And don't forget good old fashioned word of mouth! Talk it up to your family, friends, coworkers, strangers on the street! 
And finally...For those interested, I will be posting my progress throughout the challenge on this blog (I intend to do it everyday, but let's not get too ahead of ourselves, hmm?). And here are some other helpful and interesting links: Oscar-Go FSMA WebsiteSMA Research Bikram YogaBikram RochesterWith all my thanks and love, KZK

story:
Hello, my name is Blake Barnes and I am a freshman at the University of Colorado at Colorado Springs. I came to UCCS after spending my first eighteen years in Dallas, Texas. Ever since I can remember, I've had a love for sports but especially one in particular, soccer. As I grew up, I realized I had a bigger passion for soccer than any other sport. Soccer has helped me pursue my aspiration to earn a college degree as I am on scholarship to play at UCCS. It is one of the biggest blessings to be on a scholarship to play the game I love. My team has been presented with the opportunity to go to England this upcoming August as part of our preseason training to experience a once in a lifetime trip. We will get the chance to train at three professional youth academies, Fulham FC, Liverpool FC, and St. George’s, which is home to the England National Team, as well as participate in three matches while we are in England. We also get the privilege to experience the game at its highest level and watch the Emirates Cup and the Community Shield which is a cup match where the previous Premier League winner and the FA Cup winner go head to head as well as tour the great city of London and some iconic stadiums like Old Trafford, the home of Manchester United. The trip is ten days total and it would mean the world to me to get to experience the atmosphere of a soccer driven country. You will not only be contributing to a lifelong dream but also will be contributing to my team and our success in next years season. The training we will receive from the youth academies will prove crucial in our season next year as we push for a conference title and a national title next fall. The trip is a huge growth tool for my team as it gives us 10 more days of training that happens to be at the highest level possible.

The money will be going to the trip expenses as well as airfare. Our team decided to go through XL Tours to plan our trip. The money contributed will be totaled up and deposited into the XL Tours account designated for myself. Each player has their own personal account so all funds donated will be going to me specifically and not to the team as a whole. Even if I do not reach my goal of $1,500, the proceeds will still be deposited into my XL Tours account. I have four separate unique perks listed below to choose from. The first one is a special personal shout out on social networks thanking you for the donation and that is worth $5. The next perk comes after a $25 donation and I will send you a hand written thank you letter and deliver it to you via the post office. At $50, the perk is a signed team poster from the 2013 season. The poster will be signed by all the players and shipped to you for free. The best perk out of the four is the last. The perk is a UCCS soccer shirt in your respective size shipped to you. The shirt is valued at $30 including shipping and with a $150 donation; you could be supporting the Mountain Lion's soccer team from around the globe next fall on game days. In addition to the shirt, I will be sending you a hand written letter as well as a Mountain Lion scarf so you can support the team on those cold winter days.

Thank you for taking the time out of your life to read my story. This is a remarkable chance for myself to experience life in another country and compare soccer in England to soccer in the United States. I am grateful to have the opportunity at going and now I just need to raise enough money to take action. Any amount of donation will be greatly appreciated and please share with as many people you know to create awareness for my campaign. I understand that not all are able to contribute but sharing via email or social media is just as important and appreciative as a donation. The more awareness and buzz created for my campaign the better. I am truly grateful for all contributions to my campaign whether it be a donation or a share. Thank you again for your time and efforts towards my trip to England.

story:
Background: Life at Atmeh

They lost their homes, their loved ones, and in fear they fled as far as they could from bombs, bullets and torture. This is the Atmeh refugee camp, just meters away from the Turkish-Syrian border, where over 25,000 refugees, 15,000 of them children, live in squalor as a result of the humanitarian crisis produced by the ongoing conflict in Syria.

There’s no running water here, no electricity and health care is scarce. And it is the children who are most vulnerable. Sleeping in tents, they are exposed to harsh conditions and flu is endemic. With no water to wash up, lice, scabies and diseases are rampant. Drinking water is contaminated. They burn plastic when there’s no firewood, but the burning plastic emits toxic fumes that cause lung problems. And the list goes on.

What we need

Medical relief organisations have worked tirelessly to meet the needs of the camp, but with the crisis growing day by day, there is only so much they can do -- only the most essential care is being provided. But with an average of 250-300 children examined every day, and each needing as many as three different medicines -- basics like cough syrup, fever medicine, and stomach medications are always in short supply.

If we all chip in together to raise $12,000 now, we’ll be able to fill this gap in the paediatrician's medicine cabinet for one whole year, making sure sick children that come in asking for help get medicines like:

  • Cough syrup
  • Fever medicine
  • Antibiotics
  • Dehydration medicine
  • Anti-allergy pills
  • Flu and cold medicine
  • Diarrhoea medicine

We have already made a difference -- with $750 we helped Atmeh Camp’s paediatrician with one month’s supply of medicine -- but we can do even more. 

We promise

We'll be sure to send you a short video where you can see firsthand how the aid you have contributed has made a difference. Here's an example -- and you can also check for updates on our blog. 


Read more about us and our work here.

story:
Hello ! My name is Joresia Bryant- Martel.  I have been in the EMS Industry for 21 years now providing JOBS AND PATIENT CARE to the community. This year we need your help! Please help us continue to bring jobs to the community as well as SAVE PATIENTS LIVES!

PLEASE! MAKE A DONATION OF ANY $ DOLLAR AMOUNT! THANKS FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

The EMS Industry and Critical Care Patients are currently suffering due to the Medicare changes. As you may not be aware of, medicare does not cover routine medical transportation services ANYMORE and NOW our Elderly and Youth critical care patients are suffering! Please help us continue to provide services to our hurting community by "Adopting -A- Patient" today! When you adopt a patient today, you will be helping us provided a total of 2,666 ambulance transports for the next 12 months. USA EMS and other local EMS Providers will service 222 patients  per month @ the cost of $300 per transfer plus $8 per miles to service these patients. This is our reduced fee to help these patient get the medical treatment they need! If you have every used an ambulance you already know how expensive it is per ambulance transport, but because we want to help these patient, we need help covering the basic cost. USA Ambulance Service is giving 50% discounted to help at least 10 dialysis patients monthly get routine medical treatment they need. This will cost $72,000 each month to provide fully stocked BLS with MICU capabilities Ambulance Units and Staff. Our Elderly and Critical Care Patients depend on us to take care of them! Please lets NOT let them down, they need US! Thank you in advance for your support! Please tell a friend!

Check out our awesome perks that you receive when you donate at different levels. My favorite is the SAFETY LIFE JACKETS. No home should be without safety life jackets in case mother nature surprises us with a horrible hurricane like "Hurricane Katrina" did in New Orleans. So lets be prepared for this emergency situation and SAFE LIVES now and later!  "EMS-I-CARE!" project campaign

story:
Thank you for taking a moment to check out my fundraiser!  

Last year I traveled to Asia for the first time, and on a whim made the life-changing decision to add to my itinerary six weeks in Nepal, volunteering in a children's home.  The experience made an enormous impact on me.  Besides the obvious education in Nepali culture, my time here has taught me so much about love and gratitude, and about my own abilities and limitations (both greater than I had previously imagined), that I feel forever indebted to this place and these kiddos.  

That being said, I don't have a lot of skills that are particularly useful to them.  But I do have a lot of wonderful, generous people in my life that could improve their quality of life by helping me provide them with clean drinking water.  I have returned to Nepal for twice as long this year not only to give hugs, comb lice, wash clothes, and help with homework, but also on a mission to purchase and install a water filtration system that will benefit them for years to come.

As in many developing countries, access to clean water is a challenge for many Nepali people, especially those living in urban areas, where water sources are often quite polluted.  The children's home is situated on the outskirts of Kathmandu, and currently supports 30 children, from 2 to 17 years old.  Since I was here last year, the water situation in the home has improved substantially.  The well has been renovated and the number of taps doubled, giving the children much more regular access to running water on demand.  However, this water is often contaminated with bacteria and contains high levels of iron as there is no filtration system in place to make the water "potable."  This does not keep the children from drinking from the tap, as it is their only source of water. 

Where your money will go:

  • The money raised will first go toward cost of the filtration system and associated costs such as evaluation of the existing water supply, transportation, and installation.

  • If the amount raised is greater than the expenses mentioned above, the additional funds will be used to supplement the children's diet and to create an emergency medical fund to pay for illnesses and injuries they may experience.

  • Each donor will receive a unique thank you gift for her/his contribution.  Check them out in the section to the right!

Why you should care...

Though many of my sisters and brothers living in the home are not "true orphans," all are there because their families could not provide for them.  In addition to hot meals, a safe and comfortable place to sleep, and other basic living needs, the home gives the children an opportunity to attend school rather than work.  In a country where the average amount of schooling per person is 3.2 years, and up to 44% of children aged 5 to 14 work, it is no small thing that all of the kiddos in the home attend school full time and many are at the top of their class!  Safe, clean drinking water will impact their success by preventing unnecessary illness caused by pathogens in their water supply, ensuring they keep up with their studies and have the brightest possible future.

Can't donate but still want to help?

I understand that not everyone may be able to make a monetary donation, but that doesn't mean you can't help me get the word out.  Forward the link to this page to anyone that might be interested, share on social media, mention it in your knitting circles! 

You can also follow my travels and musings on my blog: www.pointscollapsing.wordpress.com
